{
  "concepts": [
    {"term": "atomic number", "category": "physics"},
    {"term": "mass number", "category": "physics"},
    {"term": "protons", "category": "physics"},
    {"term": "neutrons", "category": "physics"},
    {"term": "electrons", "category": "physics"},
    {"term": "isotopes", "category": "physics"}
  ],
  "evidence": [
    "the atomic number, denoted by Z, is simply the number of protons in the nucleus of an atom.",
    "The mass number, usually written as A, is the total number of nucleons, meaning the number of protons plus the number of neutrons.",
    "helium, the atomic number is 2, because there are two protons.",
    "the mass number is 4, because helium has two protons and two neutrons.",
    "When an atom is neutral, the number of electrons surrounding the nucleus matches the number of protons in the nucleus.",
    "Now, once we understand atomic number and mass number, we can define what isotopes are."
  ]
}

evidence: the atomic number, denoted by Z, is simply the number of protons in the nucleus of an atom.
The mass number, usually written as A, is the total number of nucleons, meaning the number of protons plus the number of neutrons.
helium, the atomic number is 2, because there are two protons.
the mass number is 4, because helium has two protons and two neutrons.
When an atom is neutral, the number of electrons surrounding the nucleus matches the number of protons in the nucleus.
Now, once we understand atomic number and mass number, we can define what isotopes are.
